Key Arguments: The submission argues that the example of misinformation provided in the Bill's Fact Sheet and Guidance Note is itself misinformation.
The author claims that MMS (Master Mineral Solution) is misrepresented in the Bill's documents and provides evidence from a guidebook to support their claim.
The submission expresses concern that the Bill exempts 'professional news content' and government-authorized content, which the author believes are sources of misinformation.
The author questions the intent behind the Bill, suggesting it protects those who spread misinformation rather than addressing the issue.
Main Themes: Criticism of exemptions for professional news and government content
Distrust in the Bill's intent and examples
Notable Quotes: I have many grave doubts, concerns and questions surrounding this Bill, when an example given in the Fact Sheet and Guide Note is Misinformation and Disinformation by the Billâ€™s own definition.

Therefore, it is my will, that this Bill does not go through parliament or any other Bill that addresses misinformation and disinformation whereby the very people who the Bill protects are in fact spreaders of misinformation and disinformation.
